content: The "Tax Fairness and Transparency Act" limits interest deduction for excessive interest of members of financial reporting groups. The "Tax Fairness and Transparency Act" limits interest deduction for excessive interest of members of financial reporting groups by amending Section 163 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Tax Fairness and Transparency Act" amends Section 163 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to limit interest deduction for excessive interest of financial reporting group members based on their proportionate share of net interest expense. The Tax Fairness and Transparency Act limits interest deduction for excessive interest of financial reporting group members based on their proportionate share of net interest expense, taxes, depreciation, and amortization as reflected on the financial reporting group's financial statements for the taxable year. The Tax Fairness and Transparency Act limits interest deduction for corporations in a financial reporting group if they fail to substantiate their share of net interest expense or elect to do so. The deduction is disallowed if interest expense exceeds 10% of adjusted taxable income. This applies to any corporation in a financial reporting group. The Tax Fairness and Transparency Act limits interest deduction for corporations in a financial reporting group if they fail to substantiate their share of net interest expense or elect to do so. The deduction is disallowed if interest expense exceeds 10% of adjusted taxable income. Certain corporations predominantly engaged in banking, financing, or with less than $5,000,000 of net interest expense are excluded from this rule. The Tax Fairness and Transparency Act limits interest deduction for corporations in a financial reporting group if they fail to substantiate their share of net interest expense or elect to do so. The deduction is disallowed if interest expense exceeds 10% of adjusted taxable income. Certain corporations predominantly engaged in banking, financing, or with less than $5,000,000 of net interest expense are excluded from this rule. The term 'net interest expense' and 'carryforward' are defined in the regulations, with specific treatment for expanded affiliated groups. The excess of interest expense over the deduction limit is added to the next year's limitation. An election must be made as per regulations, and the Secretary will provide necessary guidance for implementation. The subsection aims to coordinate interest deductibility rules, define financial services entities, allow non-US net interest expense computation for financial reporting groups, address pass-through entities treatment, and permit the use of foreign financial statements when US statements are not prepared. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2017 for corporations that are members of financial reporting groups. SEC. 3. TERMINATION OF DEFERRAL OF ACTIVE INCOME OF CONTROLLED FOREIGN CORPORATIONS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to define 'subpart F income' for controlled foreign corporations. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2017. SEC. 4. REQUIREMENT TO DISCLOSE TOTAL CORPORATE TAXES PAID. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to require issuers to disclose total pre-tax profit, State taxes, Federal taxes, and foreign taxes paid in their annual or quarterly reports. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 now mandates issuers to disclose country-by-country reporting information in their annual or quarterly reports, including revenues, profit or loss before income tax, total income tax paid, and total accrued tax expense. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires issuers to disclose country-by-country reporting information in their reports, including profits or losses, stated capital, total accumulated earnings, number of employees on a full-time equivalent basis. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires issuers to disclose country-by-country reporting information, including tangible assets' net book value, excluding cash, intangibles, and financial assets. The Commission will make this information publicly available on its website. The amendment applies to disclosures made after the enactment of this Act.
